newsitem.title: spain: GOLF-WOOSNAM CONSULTING SURGEON, CEJKA STRUGGLES.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-WOOSNAM CONSULTING SURGEON, CEJKA STRUGGLES.

text.p: Ian Woosnam said on Friday he would consult his surgeon next week to discuss the type of back operation he will need to guarantee his playing future.
The 38-year-old Briton was speaking after keeping alive his chance of a fifth victory of the year with a battling two-under-par 69 in the second round of the Volvo Masters at Valderrama.
But defending champion Alexander Cejka of Germany all but conceded his hopes despite a two-over 73.
Woosnam, who carded a first round 76, said his back felt better than last week when he was beaten by Colin Montgomerie in the first round of the World Matchplay championship in England.
"Last week it felt like someone had cut it open with a knife," said the Welshman, who suffers from spondylosis, a degeneration of the discs in his back.

"Two vertebrae are sticking out and if he (the surgeon) decided he could shave them off, I would not be away from the game too long. But if he decided to fuse them together, I would be out longer," he said.
Woosnam still has three events left on his schedule after this season-ending European Tour event.
Next month he plans to play a skins game in Asia, a tournament in Japan and the Million Dollar Challenge in South Africa.

Woosnam, second on the European money list after four victories this year, cannot catch runaway leader Montgomerie but could be caught by fourth-placed Costantino Rocca this week for the runner-up place.
Australian Robert Allenby, who hit his one shot for charity on Thursday despite a fractured sternum, is in third place.
Despite breaking his putter on Thursday, Woosnam used the same club with a new shaft on Friday and putted well with four birdies and a one-under-par back nine of 35.
Cejka, who has struggled with his game while trying to divide his time between the U.S. and European Tours this year, added a 73 to an opening 78.
"I am not feeling like last year and this is a tough golf course when you are struggling," he said.
"I have not been playing well the last couple of months. Yes, I think the title is gone. But you never know in golf. Maybe I will shoot a 62."
Tournament leader Stephen Ames of Trinidad was due to start his round later on Friday.
